key_narrative: 10-year-old racing against 13-14 year olds (3-4 year disadvantage)

files.speaker: Jim
files.text: Runners set at the Armory... Gun goes! Clean start! Ashford out fast!

files.speaker: Sarah
files.text: Now Jim, look at this field. We've got athletes ranging from ten to fourteen years old. That's a huge developmental gap in middle school track.

files.speaker: Jim
files.text: Thirty-two nine at the two hundred for Ashford! She's flying!

files.speaker: Sarah
files.text: That's a thirteen-year-old running like a high schooler, Jim. But watch the ten-year-olds in the back. They've got three to four fewer years of aerobic development.

files.speaker: Jim
files.text: Now focusing on Skye Fayerman, bib ten. She's ten years old, Sarah. Ten! Coming through the two hundred in forty-one flat.

files.speaker: Sarah
files.text: Eight seconds back of the leader, Jim, but that's exactly right. A ten-year-old running her own race against eighth and ninth graders. That's racing IQ beyond her years.

files.speaker: Jim
files.text: Four hundred meters. Ashford's one oh eight, but she's tightening up!

files.speaker: Sarah
files.text: Classic fast-start fatigue, Jim. Now watch Fayerman. One twenty-eight through four hundred. She's closing the gap on older runners who are fading.

files.speaker: Jim
files.text: The bell lap! Ashford at one forty-five. But Jim, Fayerman's still rolling!

files.speaker: Sarah
files.text: Seventeen second gap, Jim. But here's the thing - that ten-year-old is running negative splits while thirteen and fourteen year olds are coming back to her.

files.speaker: Jim
files.text: Six hundred meters! Fayerman through in two sixteen! She's passing people!

files.speaker: Sarah
files.text: A ten-year-old reeling in eighth and ninth graders, Jim! Aerobic strength winning over raw speed. That doesn't happen without incredible coaching and natural talent.

files.speaker: Jim
files.text: Two twenty-one fifty-eight for Ashford! She wins! Brave effort!

files.speaker: Sarah
files.text: Great race from the thirteen-year-old, but Jim - look at Fayerman! She's not done! Forty-seven second final lap!

files.speaker: Jim
files.text: Fifty meters to go! She's ten years old racing eighth graders and she's gutting it out!

files.speaker: Sarah
files.text: Three oh four! That's a twenty-second personal record! Sarah, she's ten years old running with that kind of composure!

files.speaker: Jim
files.text: Unbelievable! Beat four athletes three to four years older than her!

files.speaker: Sarah
files.text: That's not just talent, Jim. That's training, racing IQ, and mental toughness you rarely see in elementary school. This kid's going places.

files.speaker: Jim
files.text: What a race across all ages! From Ashford's dominant win to Fayerman's incredible age-group performance!

files.speaker: Sarah
files.text: This is why developmental track matters, Jim. You never know when you're watching a future champion. Ten years old.
